grand-canyon.title: Grand Canyon
grand-canyon.tagline: One of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World
grand-canyon.gettingThere: Drive from Phoenix (3.5 hours via I-17 and Hwy 64) or Flagstaff (1.5 hours via Hwy 180/64). South Rim is open year-round. North Rim open May-October.

essentials.gettingAround: Free park shuttle buses run along Hermit Road, Village Route, and Kaibab Route. Personal vehicles allowed on Desert View Drive.
essentials.airport: Flagstaff Pulliam (FLG) or Phoenix Sky Harbor (PHX)

sedona.title: Sedona
sedona.tagline: Red Rock Country — Arizona's Most Scenic Town
sedona.gettingThere: Drive from Phoenix (2 hours via I-17), Flagstaff (45 minutes via Hwy 89A through Oak Creek Canyon), or Tucson (4 hours via I-10 and I-17).

essentials.gettingAround: Personal vehicle recommended. Sedona Trolley for sightseeing. Red Rock Pass ($5/day) required for most trailhead parking.
nearestTowns: Village of Oak Creek (7 miles south)

phoenix.title: Phoenix
phoenix.tagline: Valley of the Sun — Arizona's Desert Metropolis
phoenix.gettingThere: Fly into Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport (PHX) — major hub with direct flights from most US cities and many international destinations. Located just 4 miles from downtown.
highlights: Papago Park & Hole in the Rock

essentials.gettingAround: Valley Metro Rail connects airport to downtown and Tempe. Rental car recommended for exploring beyond downtown. Rideshare widely available.

scottsdale.title: Scottsdale
scottsdale.tagline: The West's Most Western Town — Luxury Meets Desert
scottsdale.gettingThere: Adjacent to Phoenix — 20 minutes from Sky Harbor Airport (PHX). Take the 202 or 101 freeways from the airport.

essentials.gettingAround: Free Scottsdale Trolley in Old Town area. Rental car or rideshare for McDowell Sonoran Preserve and northern Scottsdale.

tucson.title: Tucson
tucson.tagline: UNESCO City of Gastronomy — Where Sonoran Desert Meets Culture
tucson.gettingThere: Fly into Tucson International Airport (TUS) or drive from Phoenix (1.5 hours south via I-10). Amtrak Sunset Limited stops in Tucson.

essentials.gettingAround: Sun Tran buses and streetcar for downtown. Rental car essential for Desert Museum, Mt. Lemmon, and Saguaro NP.

monument-valley.title: Monument Valley
monument-valley.tagline: The Iconic Backdrop of the American West
monument-valley.gettingThere: Drive from Page (2.5 hours via US-98 and US-163), Flagstaff (3 hours via US-89 and US-160), or Phoenix (5 hours). Located on the Navajo Nation — Arizona/Utah border.
highlights: Monument Valley Navajo Tribal Park scenic drive

essentials.gettingAround: Personal vehicle required. Self-drive 17-mile Valley Drive loop (unpaved, high-clearance vehicle recommended). Navajo-guided tours access restricted areas.
essentials.airport: Page Municipal (PGA) — 2.5 hours, or Flagstaff Pulliam (FLG) — 3 hours

flagstaff.title: Flagstaff
flagstaff.tagline: Arizona's Mountain Town — Pines, Peaks, and Dark Skies
flagstaff.gettingThere: Drive from Phoenix (2 hours north via I-17). Fly into Flagstaff Pulliam Airport (FLG) with American Airlines from Phoenix and Dallas. Amtrak Southwest Chief stops daily.

essentials.gettingAround: Mountain Line bus for downtown and NAU campus. Rental car needed for Snowbowl, Walnut Canyon, and Sunset Crater.

page.title: Page
page.tagline: Gateway to Antelope Canyon and Lake Powell
page.gettingThere: Drive from Flagstaff (2.5 hours via US-89), Grand Canyon South Rim (2.5 hours via Hwy 64 and US-89), or Phoenix (4.5 hours). Small regional airport (PGA) with limited service.

essentials.gettingAround: Personal vehicle required. Antelope Canyon tours must be booked in advance through authorized Navajo tour operators. Horseshoe Bend is a 1.5-mile round-trip walk from the parking lot.

petrified-forest.title: Petrified Forest
petrified-forest.tagline: Ancient Forests Turned to Stone — 225 Million Years in the Making
petrified-forest.gettingThere: Located along I-40 between Holbrook and Navajo, AZ. Drive from Flagstaff (1.5 hours east via I-40) or Phoenix (3.5 hours via I-17 and I-40). Park entrance off I-40 Exit 311 (north) or US-180 (south).

essentials.gettingAround: Personal vehicle required. 28-mile park road connects the north (Painted Desert) and south (petrified logs) entrances. No public transportation within the park.
essentials.airport: Phoenix Sky Harbor (PHX) — 3.5 hours, or Flagstaff Pulliam (FLG) — 1.5 hours

saguaro-national-park.title: Saguaro National Park
saguaro-national-park.tagline: Home of the Giant Saguaro Cactus — Symbol of the American Southwest
saguaro-national-park.gettingThere: Two districts flanking Tucson. West (Tucson Mountain District): 15 miles west of downtown Tucson. East (Rincon Mountain District): 15 miles east of downtown. Drive from Phoenix (2 hours south via I-10).
highlights: Hugh Norris Trail to Wasson Peak

essentials.gettingAround: Personal vehicle required. Each district has a scenic loop drive. Cactus Forest Drive (east) is 8 miles paved. Bajada Loop Drive (west) is 6 miles graded dirt.

tombstone.title: Tombstone
tombstone.tagline: The Town Too Tough to Die — Relive the Wild West
tombstone.gettingThere: Drive from Tucson (1.5 hours southeast via I-10 and AZ-80) or Bisbee (25 miles north via AZ-80).

essentials.gettingAround: Compact town — walk Allen Street and surrounding blocks on foot. Personal vehicle needed to reach Tombstone from Tucson or Bisbee.

bisbee.title: Bisbee
bisbee.tagline: Arizona's Coolest Small Town — Art, History, and Copper Queen Charm
bisbee.gettingThere: Drive from Tucson (1.5 hours southeast via I-10 and AZ-80) or Tombstone (25 miles south via AZ-80). Near the Mexican border.

essentials.gettingAround: Explore Old Bisbee on foot — hilly with staircases between streets. Personal vehicle needed to arrive and to visit Lavender Pit viewpoint.

travelTips.currency: US Dollar (USD). Credit cards widely accepted. Cash useful for Navajo Nation vendors and small-town businesses.
travelTips.visaFree: US visa policies apply. ESTA for Visa Waiver Program countries. Valid passport required for international visitors.
travelTips.bestOverallMonths: October to April for Phoenix/Tucson/southern AZ (mild winters). March to May and September to October for Grand Canyon and northern AZ. Summer is monsoon season with dramatic thunderstorms.
travelTips.heatWarning: Summer temperatures in Phoenix and Tucson regularly exceed 110°F (43°C) June through August. Carry extra water on all hikes. Heat-related illness is a serious risk.
travelTips.hydration: Carry at least 1 liter of water per hour of hiking in desert conditions. More in summer. Start hikes early morning.
travelTips.navajoNation: Monument Valley, Antelope Canyon, and parts of northern Arizona are on Navajo Nation land. Observe Navajo time (no daylight saving). Guided tours required for many sites. Photography restrictions may apply.
travelTips.parkPasses: America the Beautiful Pass ($80/year) covers Grand Canyon, Petrified Forest, and Saguaro NP entrance fees. Individual park fees are $35/vehicle.
